name: aluminium chloride production | aluminium chloride | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/17015/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of aluminium chloride from the reaction of aluminium melt and hot chlorine gas at high temperatures.;Aluminium chloride can be produced by the reaction of aluminium with chlorine gas and of aluminium or aluminium hydrozide with hydrochloric acid (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt et al. 2007). This product is used to derive aluminium powder which is used in the fabrication of solar cells and electromagnetic fields (Lee et al. 2011). Aluminium chloride is also “[…] widely applied as acid catalyst, isomerization of hydrocarbon, catalyst of aldehyde synthesis, and catalyst of cation polymerization. In case of an anhydride, it is also used for cracking of oil, and catalyst of Friedel-Crafts reaction in an organic synthesis” (Lee et al. 2011, pp. 40).;The final product has usually a shading of yellow and gray caused by residues of the reactants. The pure product would instead have a white colour (Helmboldt 2007). Anhydrous aluminium chloride is a hydroscopic, solid that reacts with moisture and air. Aluminium chloride is soluble in chlorinated solvents, while it forms a complex when being dissolved in polar aprotic solvents (Kirk et al. 2004).;In this dataset, the raw material inputs, and process-specific material exchanges, are modelled with a generic stoichiometry-based tool, using literature or estimated yields. The emissions are modelled with a default value, which is estimated  based on losses, unreacted chemicals, among others. The auxiliary (i.e., cooling water and infrastructure) and energy consumption exchanges are modelled with a default value based on industry data from literature sources.   For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;Reference(s):;Lee, D. et al. 2011. CHEMICAL SYNTHESIS OF ALUMINUM CHLORIDE (AlCl3) BY COST-EFFECTIVE REDUCTION PROCESS. Rev.Adv.Mater. Sci. 28, pp.40-43;Helmboldt, O. et al. 2007. Aluminum Compounds, Inorganic. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Electronic Release, Vol.2, pp.569-584. Wiley-VCH, Weinheim.;Kirk, Raymond E., Donald F. Othmer, and Charles A. Mann. "Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology." 2004.

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: In the past years the most common method of production of aluminium chloride have been the reaction of aluminium and chlorine gas at high temperatures (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt 2007).;The time period spans from the earliest year from which at least one of the input values was obtained until 2020, but overall form the most realistic picture of the production. Besides, the activity is partly generated, in terms of material inputs and outputs, based on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields, which does not expect to change over time.;The source of information for the heat, electricity, water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. The end time period is therefore set based on the years from Gendorf reference.;For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure and in the comments of the exchanges.;Reference(s):;Lee, D. et al. 2011. CHEMICAL SYNTHESIS OF ALUMINUM CHLORIDE (AlCl3) BY COST-EFFECTIVE REDUCTION PROCESS. Rev.Adv.Mater. Sci. 28, pp.40-43;Helmboldt, O. et al. 2007. Aluminum Compounds, Inorganic. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Electronic Release, Vol.2, pp.569-584. Wiley-VCH, Weinheim.;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled at the Global level. The main material inputs and outputs of this activity are generated with on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields.  Furthermore, the source of information for the heat, electricity, water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure. ;The dataset could also be considered as not geography-specific, and thus, valid for a broader geographical coverage.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In the past years the most common method of production of aluminium chloride have been the reaction of aluminium and chlorine gas at high temperatures (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt 2007). Notably, the alluminum could be sourced as a scrap, secondary ingot or prime ingot (Kirk et al. 2004). Chlorine gas is blown in baths of aluminium melt using cylindrical reactors with ceramic lining (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt 2007). This reaction is exothermic with a heat delta of 1.41 MJ/mol, the reaction requires temperatures between 670 to 850 degrees Celsius.;Chemical reaction:;2Al + 3Cl2 -> 2AlCl3;The product sublimes through the melt pool and subsequently condenses into a vessel where it also solidifies on the condenser walls. The generated crystals of aluminium chloride are periodically removed, processed, and packed under a dry air or nitrogen atmosphere (Kirk et al. 2004). The hot gas that exits the melt pool is filtered to remove entrained liquids and solids, while the off-gases are purified before recycling.;In this dataset, a yield of 95% was assumed, with a 95% recirculation for the remaining 5% of unreacted aluminium. Finally, the residual alluminium was assumed to be sent for landfill.;Reference(s):;Lee, D. et al. 2011. CHEMICAL SYNTHESIS OF ALUMINUM CHLORIDE (AlCl3) BY COST-EFFECTIVE REDUCTION PROCESS. Rev.Adv.Mater. Sci. 28, pp.40-43;Helmboldt, O. et al. 2007. Aluminum Compounds, Inorganic. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Electronic Release, Vol.2, pp.569-584. Wiley-VCH, Weinheim.;Kirk, Raymond E., Donald F. Othmer, and Charles A. Mann. "Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology." 2004.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Literature data and stoichiometric calculation. This inventory is partially based on a generic model of the production of chemicals. The data generated by this model have been improved with compound-specific data when available. The model of the production of chemicals is using specific industry or literature data wherever possible and more generic data on chemical production processes to fill compound-specific data gaps when necessary. The basic principles of the model have been published in literature (Hischier, 2005). The model has been updated and extended with newly available data from the chemical industry.In the model, unreacted fractions are treated in a waste treatment process, and emissions reported are after a waste treatment process that is included in the scope of this dataset. For volatile reactants, a small level of evaporation is assumed. Solvents and catalysts are mostly recycled in closed-loop systems within the scope of the dataset and reported flows are for losses from this system.The main source of information for the values for heat, electricity, water (process and cooling), nitrogen, and chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information refer to the comments of the exchanges.

References:
Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit 
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description: Aluminium chloride can be produced by the reaction of aluminium with chlorine gas and of aluminium or aluminium hydrozide with hydrochloric acid (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt et al. 2007). This product is used to derive aluminium powder which is used in the fabrication of solar cells and electromagnetic fields (Lee et al. 2011). Aluminium chloride is also “[…] widely applied as acid catalyst, isomerization of hydrocarbon, catalyst of aldehyde synthesis, and catalyst of cation polymerization. In case of an anhydride, it is used for cracking of oil, and catalyst of Friedel-Crafts reaction in an organic synthesis” (Lee et al. 2011, pp. 40). The final product has usually a shading of yellow and gray caused by residues of the reactants. The pure product would instead have a white colour (Helmboldt 2007). Reference(s): Lee, D. et al. 2011. CHEMICAL SYNTHESIS OF ALUMINUM CHLORIDE (AlCl3) BY COST-EFFECTIVE REDUCTION PROCESS. Rev.Adv.Mater. Sci. 28, pp.40-43 Helmboldt, O. et al. 2007. Aluminum Compounds, Inorganic. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Electronic Release, Vol.2, pp.569-584. Wiley-VCH, Weinheim.

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of compressed air in the years 2015-2019 was 1113557454 m3 per year. This equals 0.45216 m3/kg chemical produced. exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of river water in the years 2015-2019 was 22000820 t per year. However, since the cooling water is modelled as an input, the amount of river water was adjusted to avoid double counting. 55% of the input amount of cooling water was deducted from the amount of river water, as that is the share of river water versus well water. This equals 0.00096543 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

flow.name: Water, river
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. To determine the emissions of water to air, the difference of all water inputs (from river, well, tap water and cooling) and outputs (wastewater, emissions to water) was calculated. The average ouput of water to air in the years 2015-2019 was 3620444 m3 per year. This equals 0.00147 m3/kg chemical produced. For more information on the other water exchanges please consult the respective exchange comment. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average amount of cooling water released in the years 2015-2019 was 34408800 t per year. It was assumed that 5% of the cooling water was emitted to air during its use, therefore, to calculate the input of cooling water, the output value reported by GENDORF was scaled up by the factor 1/0.95. This equals 0.014707 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on stoichiometric calculations and literature data. 26.981539g/mol is the molar mass of aluminium, primary, liquid (Al). 133.339639g/mol is the molar mass of aluminium chloride (AlCl3). In the past years the most common method of production of aluminium chloride have been the reaction of aluminium and chlorine gas at high temperatures (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt 2007). Chlorine gas is blown in baths of aluminium using cylindrical reactors with ceramic lining (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt 2007). This reaction is exothermic with a heat delta of 1.41 MJ/mol, the reaction requires temperatures between 670 to 850 degrees Celsius. Chemical reaction: 2Al + 3Cl2 -> 2AlCl3 With a yield of 95%, 0.213 kg of aluminium is necessary. Of the remaing 5%, recirculation of 95% was assumed (equals 4.75% of entire input), therefore it was subtracted from the input. The remaining 5% (0.25% of entire input) was sent to landfill.

Chlorine gas is blown in baths of aluminium using cylindrical reactors with ceramic lining (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt 2007). This reaction is exothermic with a heat delta of 1.41 MJ/mol, the reaction requires temperatures between 670 to 850 degrees Celsius. Chemical reaction: 2Al + 3Cl2 -> 2AlCl3

The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of steam (internal and external sources) in the years 2015-2019 was 511785800 MJ per year. This equals 0.2078 MJ/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The amount of water released back to the environment consists of the sum of the amount of process water treated in the internal WWTP that is then released back to the environment and the amount of cooling water released back to the environment. The average ouput of the internal WWTP in the years 2015-2019 was 2628800 m3 and that of cooling water released back to the environment was 34408800 m3. This gives a yearly average of 37037600 m3 emissions of water to water. This equals 0.01504 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. References: Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The values is based on a generic model. The basic principles of the model have been published in literature (Hischier 2005, Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability). The model has been updated and extended with newly available data from the chemical industry. Find more information in the dedicated report on the ecoinvent website. Reference(s): Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59–67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7

flow.name: Aluminium III
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of well water in the years 2015-2019 was 18607480 t per year. However, since the cooling water is modelled as an input, the amount of well water was adjusted to avoid double counting. 45% of the input amount of cooling water was deducted from the amount of well water, as that is the share of well water versus river water. This equals 0.00081652 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

flow.name: Water, well, in ground
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on stoichiometric calculations and literature data. 26.981539g/mol is the molar mass of aluminium, primary, liquid (Al). 133.339639g/mol is the molar mass of aluminium chloride (AlCl3). In the past years the most common method of production of aluminium chloride have been the reaction of aluminium and chlorine gas at high temperatures (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt 2007). Chlorine gas is blown in baths of aluminium using cylindrical reactors with ceramic lining (Lee et al. 2011 and Helmboldt 2007). This reaction is exothermic with a heat delta of 1.41 MJ/mol, the reaction requires temperatures between 670 to 850 degrees Celsius. Chemical reaction: 2Al + 3Cl2 -> 2AlCl3 With a yield of 95%, 0.213 kg of aluminium is necessary. Of the remaing 5%, recirculation of 95% was assumed (equals 4.75% of entire input), therefore it was subtracted from the input. The remaining 5% (0.25% of entire input) was sent to landfill.
